name: Life Cycle Support
description: The organization manages the information system using a system development life cycle methodology that includes information security considerations.
supplemental_guidance: NIST Special Publication 800-64 provides guidance on security considerations in the system development life cycle.

rev5.name: System Development Life Cycle
rev5.changes_from_rev4: Control text adds privacy Discussion is expanded to include benefits of effective integration of  security and privacy requirements into enterprise architecture

attack_techniques.name: Valid Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Incorporating security throughout the system development lifecycle ensures that default accounts are identified, modified, or removed before deployment, reducing valid account exploitation opportunities.

attack_techniques.name: Default Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: SDLC security practices that mandate changing or disabling default credentials before production deployment prevent adversaries from exploiting factory-default accounts for initial access.

attack_techniques.name: Local Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Lifecycle security requirements that enforce unique local account passwords and disable unnecessary local accounts during system provisioning prevent local credential reuse across environments.

attack_techniques.name: Cloud Accounts
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: SDLC practices that enforce least-privilege cloud IAM policies and review service account permissions during development prevent overprivileged cloud accounts from reaching production.

attack_techniques.name: Code Repositories
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Security-aware SDLC practices that enforce code repository access controls, secret scanning, and branch protection prevent adversaries from accessing sensitive code and credentials through development repositories.

attack_techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: SDLC security practices that enforce DLL side-loading prevention through manifest-based assembly binding and proper library search path configuration eliminate side-loading vulnerabilities before deployment.
